title: Talking to He Who Knows
excerpt: A lil something about venting to Allah and not feeling so lost after.
content:
Everyone has problems. You’re sad, I’m sad—everyone’s sad in their own way. But everyone also has their own way of facing those problems, their own way of conquering them. Some distract themselves, some hurt themselves (though that’s never the answer), and some choose to share their struggles—with friends, family, or even their pets—and somehow feel lighter afterward.

Me? I’ve never really felt that telling someone about my problems helps. It doesn’t relieve anything, and it definitely doesn’t solve the problem. I’m not the kind of person who finds comfort in explaining things out loud, because deep down, I already know no one can truly fix it for me. People can listen, they can empathize—but the problem will still be mine to face in the end.

So whenever life starts to feel a little too heavy, I turn to Allah. I talk to Him in my own way—sometimes through prayer, sometimes just in silence. I ask for guidance, for strength, for a way out that I might not be seeing yet.

But then I start to wonder. If Allah already knows everything—my struggles, my thoughts, even the things I can’t put into words—then what’s the point of telling Him? Do I really need to say it out loud? Shouldn’t I just focus on solving the problem, knowing that He already understands every part of it, every corner of my heart?

I’ve always been the type who doesn’t pay much attention to emotions. When something goes wrong, my first instinct is to fix it. I don’t cry, I don’t dwell, I just move. Maybe I tell myself that emotions won’t solve anything—but deep down, I think I just don’t know how to sit with them.

But the more I think about it, the more I realize that maybe that’s not always the healthiest way to live. Maybe sometimes, emotions aren’t meant to be solved. They’re meant to be felt. To remind me that I’m human, that I’m not built to carry everything on my own.

So sometimes, even though I tell myself there’s no point, I still talk to Allah. And when I do, I feel something… different. It’s not dramatic or magical, but it’s real. A quiet kind of peace. A soft relief that doesn’t erase the problem but makes it a little easier to face.

I still have to deal with everything—I still have to make choices, take action, find solutions. But somehow, after I’ve poured it all out to Him, I don’t feel as lost anymore. It’s as if, even though nothing around me has changed, something inside me has.

And maybe that’s the point. Maybe talking to Allah isn’t about giving Him information He already knows—it’s about reminding myself that I’m not alone in carrying it. It’s about pausing for a moment to breathe, to acknowledge my weakness, and to let that be okay.

Well, I know it’s not for Him. It’s for me. For my heart. For the parts of me that don’t always get heard or understood, even by myself.

Because when I speak to Allah, I’m not seeking validation. I’m not trying to explain myself or find someone to agree with me. I’m simply grounding myself in the One who already understands everything I can’t say.

And the truth is, life will always keep moving. Problems will come and go. Some I’ll solve quickly, some will take time, and some might never go away at all. But knowing that I can always turn to Allah—whether to ask for help, to complain, to cry, or simply to be—makes all the difference.

It reminds me that no matter how strong I try to be, I’ll always need Him. And that’s not weakness—that’s mercy. It’s comfort. It’s the quiet kind of strength that comes from knowing I don’t have to hold everything together on my own.

So maybe that’s what I should always remember: that no matter how heavy things get, I’ll always have Allah. And as long as I have Him, I’ll never really be alone. Because sometimes, the answer isn’t in escaping the storm—it’s in realizing that even through it, I’m still being guided.
